awd_titl_txt: The Role of Temperature-Driven Chemical Reactions in the Evolution of Solar System Ices
awd_abstract_narration:
Many of the icy satellites in the outer Solar System have low surface and subsurface temperatures.  Spacecraft measurements at both Jupiter's satellite Europa and Saturn's satellite Enceladus measured various molecular species on their surfaces.  Recent work by the Principal Investigator and his colleagues have shown that these molecular species react at low temperatures (~80 K), well within the range of these lower satellite surface temperatures.  Using this grant, the investigators will study the role that temperature-driven reactions of ices of different chemical compositions play in the evolution of icy objects within the Solar System.   They will use the newly-designed ultra-high vacuum laboratory at Northern Arizona University.  Ice samples will be created under conditions similar to those where Solar System ices are found, and then studied as they are heated at various rates.  This project supports the mission of the NSF by promoting our understanding of the chemical evolution of icy objects in the outer Solar System.  The PI will include graduate and undergraduate students in this research, speak to a local elementary school, as well as give science presentations at the Flagstaff Festival of Science.


Ice samples containing oxidants (ozone and hydrogen peroxide) and various sulfur-, carbon-, and nitrogen-containing compounds will be prepared under conditions relevant to Solar System ices and characterized with infrared spectroscopy. Then, the samples will be warmed at various rates, while being monitored with infrared spectroscopy, mass spectrometry and microbalance gravimetry. This combination of techniques allows new products to be identified and the destruction of existing ones to be monitored. Heating the sample at different rates allows for the calculation of the activation energies for the reaction. Finally, the concentration will be varied in these mixtures, which will help to elucidate the reactions pathways that are active in these different chemical systems.  The results of this new work will have strong implications on how our Solar System may evolve over time and could change how modelers and theorists view the role that non-radiolytic processes play in the chemical evolution of not only solar system ices but also other objects, such as comets or interstellar ices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This work is a laboratory study focusing on trying to understand how the structure and composition of cold icy surfaces in our Solar System (primarily moons of Jupiter) may change over time. While the primary focus of this study deals with investigating chemical reactions that will occur simply due to temperature, we also investigated how energetic electrons, which constantly are impacting airless bodies in outer space, can alter the composition and structure of the main solid component (water ice) typically present at the surface of these cold objects.

We have measured how efficiently energetic electrons can eject water ice from these cold surfaces (sputtering), how quickly electrons can change the structure of water ice (amorphization), and how quickly electrons can destroy pores (compaction) that are present in extraterrestrial water ice. Taking into account the number of electrons that are actually hitting the surfaces of these icy bodies, these findings show that electrons can produce comparable effects to other sources of radiation that are simultaneously hitting these surfaces (ultraviolet light, energetic ions).  Thus, we predict that electrons will play a key role in altering the surface composition and structure of any cold object in our Solar System, and that these changes will likely be observable through various remote sensing techniques (reflectance spectroscopy) or even in future space missions.

We have also sought to simulate the possible surface composition in regions of Europa, a moon of Jupiter, to determine whether some of the compounds would react at the very low temperatures (~100 K) present on the surface.  In this work, we focused on water ice, hydrogen sulfide and ozone.  Water ice is the dominant material on most cold objects in outer space, while hydrogen sulfide and ozone both likely form from reactions between water ice and particles that hit the surface of Europa.  Hydrogen sulfide likely forms from reactions between sulfur particles from Io, a moon of Jupiter, that implant into the water ice surface, and ozone likely forms from oxygen made when the chemical bonds of water are broken by energetic particles.  We show that under conditions of Europa (cold temperature, low pressure) that hydrogen sulfide efficiently reacts with ozone and find that new compounds such as sulfur dioxide, sulfuric acid, sulfuric acid hydrates, hydrogen peroxide and oxygen can be formed and are detectable with reflectance spectroscopy, a common technique used by scientists to characterize outer Solar System objects. These results have direct implications for Europa, where many of these compounds have been identified or are suspected to be present.  More generally, these results also show that even at the relatively low temperatures thermally-driven chemical reactions are important for extraterrestrial icy objects and can significantly alter the surface composition, which may have a profound effect on what scientists observe when they are attempting to characterize the surface composition of any of these objects in the future.
